page.title: 08LEVINGTON VILLAGE
page.content: The old church and the Ship Inn are next to each other and nearer the creek than the rest of the village. Levington Creek was once used for smuggling and by barges. Thames Sailing Barges used to bring stone and gravel to the wharf at the head of the creek. The stone and gravel were used to repair the roads. Today the creek is silted up. The village green is the smallest registered in England. Most of the houses in Levington are spread along the main road because the survivors of the Black Death moved away from the infected area by the church. When Fisons built their laboratories at Levington they also built an estate of houses for their workers. When Norsk Hydro bought the premises, they sold the houses. There are no shops in the village, and the nearest Primary School is at Nacton.
